data.title: Fantastic Coin Exhibit
data.text: I hadn’t expected to find two modest coin cabinets in Memorial Hall. Some fluorescent bulbs were burned out and I didn’t notice any signage outside the cases.  Expecting a modest display of grandpa’s box of funny money, imagine my shock at seeing, first thing, a brilliant flashing 1907 Ultra High Relief St. Gaudens Double Eagle proof.  This is a stunning coin, especially “in the raw” without a distracting plastic "slab".  Accompanying this treasure were about 75 “fully original” US coins of all denominations, including an 1815 Quarter Dollar AU-U, 1839-O half Unc, 1796 Quarter Dollar Gem Unc, a run of Connecticut coppers, and an1862 gem proof $3 gold.  Labeling was minimal and the coins were just laid in the cases, showing only one side.  While some might prefer a more sophisticated display, I liked this one.  It is what one would have seen when visiting the owner in his home with his treasures laid out on his library table for inspection – no pretension and no flash.

data.title: Gold mine of Information
data.text: I had traveled to Connecticut to do genealogical research and the Library offered so much that could not be found elsewhere.  The staff was beyond helpful.  Loved the card files and actually found a death record that I had been searching for, for over 13 years.  If the staff had not given me the map showing the changing of the towns I would have never found the document. Hope to get back there again.

data.title: Up from Texas to do genealogy
data.text: I spent a couple of hours here on a Saturday morning.  Street parking on Saturdays is free and they open a parking lot that is usually for staff.  The building is relatively deserted and you have to find the correct doorway to enter, but if you follow the directions carefully, it is all good.  I could have spent two days here but I was on the last day of my week in CT so my time was limited.  The two staff members I had questions for were wonderful and very patient and willing to help.  My ancestors helped found several CT towns in the 1600s so I need to plan another trip.  Allow a lot of time here if you intend to do serious research.  Some materials need to be requested in advance so check out the website before going.

data.title: Unparalleled
data.text: This is THE place to study Connecticut history and genealogy. Their collections are unparalleled, much of it unique. The staff is friendly and helpful. Do walk upstairs to the law library and the wonderful small museum. Can't beat the price, which is free!

data.title: Ct should restore this gem
data.text: The support staff and the materials are outstanding.  I was researching the 1870s and the newspaper on site materials were incredibly helpful.  Off site materials can be ordered and delivered within a day or so.  The rules for the use of archive materials are apprpriately enforced.  I did not visit the museum.  The interior needs to be restored and regilted to bring the building to its 1907 glory. State should drop a few bucks here like they did across the street.  On street metered parking is available or if you're willing to walk a bit, you can park at the Legislative parking garage for free.  On Saturdays, you can park behind the museum in its lot.

data.title: History Buffs Delight
data.text: The State of Connecticut has opened the renovated Library filling it with artifacts and historic memorablia.  It's a pleasant diversion for a history buff but don't go out of you way to visit.  It'll be there when you want to walk by

data.title: Colt Museum How the West was Won!
data.text: Wow one of the best Library's in Connecticut, it has a wonderful Colt Gun Museum that shares how the west was won!   It also has a lot of Connecticut history and art.   A must see for the whole family.

data.title: A Research Trip
data.text: We were here doing genealogical research. The staff was friendly, very cooperative in their help and it is a great resource for research of Connecticut colonial families.

data.title: Connecticut State History
data.text:
I love all museums. While I had a good experience at this attraction, I was disappointed in the condition of the exhibits and the fact that it doesn't look like it has been updated in 50 years except to put a posted of Ella Grasso on top of an old voting booth maybe 35 years ago.
When you walk in the building, the supreme court is to your right, the library is to your left and the museum is straight ahead. 
The highlight of the museum is the original Royal Charter signed by King Charles II in 1662. The signage is poor and not very interesting nor interactive, but the significance of having the original document available for public viewing is pretty great.
The rest of the museum is filled with snippets of CT history and trivia including flags, uniforms, guns, and other equipment either made in CT or important to its history.

data.title: very helpful
data.text: I am doing research on my Great Great Uncle who served in the Civil War. Lots of resources and lots of nice people to help you out.  Have to go back to look at more books and papers.

data.title: A Very Informative Place Indeed!
data.text: I visited this place with a group of friends, all students of history. This place with its collection of newspapers, directories and a host of other archives interested me a lot! It was an amazing feeling to go through some of the collection which were very old but were equally valuable. Great information on the Revolutionary War Period! Am Glad that I got a chance to visit this place, would surely like to come back again and again to visit this storehouse of information.

data.title: Real Genealogy-did I spell that write?
data.text: This place is a real treat but is almost always empty. The old newspaper clippings are a wonder to behold. I found where my Grandfather had his Paint Store & my aunt's wedding announcement.

data.title: More than old books
data.text: The place to go to research early times in Connecticut, New England, or the United State.  Great place to research a term paper (which I did).  One of a kind books that offer information that you cannot get elsewhere.  Many other facets to observe, other collections such as early coinage.

data.title: A Hidden Gem
data.text: Across Capital Avenue from the State Capitol is a building housing the State Library and Archives, the State Supreme Court, and tucked away, a wonderful museum.  The Colt gun display alone is worth the trip, but there is much else to see.

data.title: Wonderful Staff Great place to research your Connecticut Ancestors
data.text: Resources are wonderful, hours generous.  The Staff at the library are very knowledgeable and friendly!

data.title: Genealogist's Favorite Resource
data.text: Researchers can find a wealth of CT information. Directories, Newspapers, published Family books, Military, Church, and so much more!   Staff is very helpful.

data.title: Into History?
data.text: Amazing staff.  Simply amazing.  And the archives are beyond amazing when researching Connecticut history.  If nothing else, just stop by and browse the collections, some of which are extremely old and require wearing gloves to view.  Amazing for true historians, especially for the Revolutionary War period and Connecticut's role...

data.title: Looking for dead relatives?
data.text: This is a great place to find out more.  They have copies of family histories as well as books on different locals which mention early inhabitants.

data.title: CT State Library
data.text: If you are interested in state history or genealogy it is an awesome research facility/museum.  The staff is incredible.

data.title: Be sure to stop in here if you're in the State House area
data.text:
BEAUTIFUL space... worth at least a walk-through for aesthetic appreciation.

WiFi, too!
